text: So team, I've got some questions around this email we plan on sending out... how are we actually going about this? Will we use a service like MailChimp that I can design/modify a template with, or are we doing it from scratch on our own? I know it's just going to be a link + short message and branding, but if it's anything beyond plain text w/ a logo image attached, I need to know how to approach designing the email itself.
yeah - it's a good question.
I suspect that individual clients have a service they use currently
which would be good to find out <@U026AP8CM>

attachments.text: Want to learn how to code your own HTML email campaigns? It helps if you have experience coding HTML web pages, but if you don't, MailChimp can point you in the right direction.

text: I'm sure it's biased in getting you to use MailChimp specifically but it shows a lot of the roadblocks you run into with sending HTML email to subscribers/users.

and i'm not making an argument like dean — I'm not suggesting we need to literally see every article moving into place
just trying to keep it lean and to the point

well i think it does the job of conveying what's going on
my broad concerns are that it could represent a bunch of animation
The animation stuff is more smoke and mirrors, it's the show around something actually happening, but we can cut it down if we want to minimize it.
and in the hypothetical case (thinking out loud here) that somebody added a bunch — would they have to wait for all the articles to 'migrate' to the phone before they're done?
maybe we could start with the articles that are onscreen and then select up to a maximum number of off-screen articles for the animation

Yeah, I definitely don't think this current motion concept should include all articles in the list. I just want a way to demonstrate that these articles are moving from the list, to the phone—that transaction stage. Doesn't need to be a 1-to-1 thing, which is also why I liked not having anything but a big checkmark show up on screen. I think anything completely off-screen moving toward the phone wouldn't make sense (as the path from off screen to a phone partially off screen would never show on screen). If we wanted to give the illusion of more things "happening" after all on screen articles make their move, that's what the circle/spinner loading before the check mark would be for.

We can consider other methods of showing these articles transferring to phone, ones without as much motion if that sounds like a better way to go. That's fine with me, I just want to understand what the important thing is to show after users submit their reading list.
